questions.question: How many people in Australia experience homelessness every night?

imageMetadata.resources:
There are 116,427 people homeless in Australia (0.5% of the population). That means on any given night in Australia, 1 in 200 people are homeless.

Source: ABS2049.0 - Census of Population and Housing: Estimating homelessness, 2016. (http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/mf/2049.0)

questions.question: Which situation does not come under the definition of homelessness?

choices.answer: Living in a house that is severely crowded
Living in a spare room at your Aunty's house

imageMetadata.resources:
All of the above situations – there is no one definition of homelessness. The ABS statistical definition states that a person is considered homeless if their current living arrangement:
●	Is in a dwelling that is inadequate; or
●	Has no tenure, or if their initial tenure is short and not extendable; or
●	Does not allow them to have control of, and access to space for social relations. 

Source:  ABS. (2012). 4922.0 - Information Paper - A Statistical Definition of Homelessness. (http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/mf/4922.0)

questions.question: What percentage of homeless people are sleeping rough?

imageMetadata.resources:
There are more than 116,000 homeless people in Australia. But less than seven percent of that figure actually sleeps ‘rough’. There are still more than 8,000 people sleeping rough or in improvised dwellings, for example sleeping in tents or cars, in Australia

Source: ABS2049.0 - Census of Population and Housing: Estimating homelessness, 2016. (http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/mf/2049.0)

questions.question: What order do the top causes of homelessness occur in (from most to least)?

choices.answer: Housing crisis, money difficulties, domestic violence
Housing crisis, domestic violence, money difficulties
Domestic  violence, housing crisis, money difficulties
Domestic violence, money difficulties, housing crisis

imageMetadata.resources:
When people seek assistance from specialist homelessness services, they provide a main reason for seeking assistance:
27% cited domestic and family violence.
24% cited the housing crisis.
10% cited financial difficulties.

Homelessness is often a result of a number of complex issues, which can include all of the above and more. 

People seeking assistance can also provide more than one reason for seeking assistance. Looking at these statistics, it is clear that these people often have more than one reason for seeking assistance (as the total figured adds up to 118.5% indicating some respondents selected more than one reason):
37% cited domestic and family violence.
43.7% cited the housing crisis.
37.8% cited financial difficulties.

Source: AIHW. (2016). Specialist Homelessness services annual report. (https://www.aihw.gov.au/reports/homelessness-services/specialist-homelessness-services-2016-17/data)

questions.question: What was the accepted poverty line in 2016?

imageMetadata.resources:
Any family with an income below what is considered to represent an ‘austere’ standard of living is considered to be living in poverty. In Australia, the Henderson Poverty Line developed by the Melbourne Institute has been the standard used by researchers since the 1970s. Inclusive of housing costs For a single person not working, the poverty line is currently $420.16 per week, or $60.02 per day. For a family comprising two adults, one of whom is working, and two dependent children, it’s $973.26 per week ($139.04 per day).

Source: https://www.vinnies.org.au/page/Publications/National/Factsheets_and_policy_briefings/Briefing_paper_Are_allowances_adequate

questions.question: What was the Newstart Allowance in 2018?

imageMetadata.resources: The two main extra payments received by Newstart recipients are Commonwealth Rent Assistance and the Energy Supplement. For simplicity, here we only examine the rate for a single person under 60 years of age, living independently, without dependants. The maximum rate of benefit is used in each instance.

questions.question: How many people experiencing homelessness in Australia are under the age of 25?

imageMetadata.resources:
Answer: 38% - almost half of all the homeless population in Australia are under the age of 25. Nearly 60% were under the age of 35.

Source: ABS2049.0 - Census of Population and Housing: Estimating homelessness, 2016. (http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/mf/2049.0)

What proportion of people experiencing homelessness are older Australians (over the age of 55)?

imageMetadata.resources:
Older Australians (over the age of 55) make up around 16% of the homeless population, yet they only represent 8% of those accessing specialist homelessness services in 2015–16.

Source: AIHW. (2016). Specialist Homelessness services annual report. (https://www.aihw.gov.au/reports/homelessness-services/specialist-homelessness-services-2016-17/data)

questions.question: Around 288,000 people sought help at homeless agencies in 2016-17. In the last year this:

imageMetadata.resources:
Answer: The number of people seeking assistance has increased by 3% in the last 12 months. Homelessness is a growing crisis in Australia.

Source:  AIHW (2016). Specialist Homelessness services annual report. (https://www.aihw.gov.au/reports/homelessness-services/specialist-homelessness-services-2016-17/data)
